accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist. When requesting audiovisual material, please refer to the Title and the AV Number (example: AV 1916). Researchers are asked to check the "Restrictions" note for each Title. If a Title does not currently have an access copy, please contact an RAC archivist for further instruction.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records of the National Committee on United States – China Relations are divided into ten record groups, which reflect the order in which the records were received (but which are otherwise an artificial distinction). The records are sorted intellectually into series, which carry over through all record groups, but they have received minimal physical rearrangement. RG 9 of the NCUSCR records is arranged into thirteen series: 1 - Events; 2 - Exchanges - General; 3 - Exchanges to China; 4 - Exchanges from China; 5 - Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues; 6 - Publications and Reports; 8 - Programs, Projects, and Proposals; 9 - Ping Pong Diplomacy; 10 - Development; 11 – Board of Directors, Committees, and Members records; 14 – NCUSCR Presidents' Files; 15 – Clippings and Reference; and 16 - Special Formats - General.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The National Committee on United States – China Relations (NCUSCR) was established in 1966 as a nonprofit educational organization with a mission to encourage mutual understanding and dialogue between citizens of the United States and China. The National Committee came into being through the cooperative efforts of scholars and civic, religious, and business leaders who, at a time of mutual hostility between the two countries, sought to stimulate public discussion about China and the United States' relations with it by sponsoring conferences, seminars, publications, and other education and outreach programs. In 1972, the National Committee sponsored the Chinese table tennis team's historic U. S. visit. This round of "Ping Pong Diplomacy," which followed closely on Richard Nixon's visit to China in February 1972, helped pave the way for later exchanges and, eventually, for the normalization of relations with China in 1979. Building on these cultural exchanges, the National Committee came to be a primary organizer of professional and policy exchanges between the two countries (and including Hong Kong and Taiwan), in the areas of foreign affairs and international relations, economic development, governance and legal affairs, education, mass media, environmental and global issues, etc. As its role in exchanges became more prominent, the National Committee turned over some of its educational programs to the Asia Society in the late 1970s, but it continues its educational role through public education events and ongoing outreach. Funding for the National Committee comes from the United States government (especially the Department of State), corporations, and foundations, as well as from its individual membership.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The National Committee on United States-China Relations donated its records to the Rockefeller Archive Center by deed of gift dated March 27, 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: RG 9, the final segment of the NCUSCR records, includes materials from multiple series and notably contains several early organizational and program files that the National Committee considered historical records. In addition to materials in the Board of Directors, Committees, and Members files, RG 9 includes records of the seminal April 1965 Conference on the United States and China. The Presidents' Files series contains Arthur H. Rosen's chronological files for the full period of his tenure, 1975-1987. Other materials of note include reference and reports files on various Travelers to China and records of NCUSCR Members' Trips to China; records of the University Field Staffs, mainly for the 1970s; the Civil Society in China project, circa 1997-2000; and public relations, press, and correspondence files for the Chinese Table Tennis Delegation visit to the U. S. in 1972. Finally, the Clippings and Reference series includes, among other materials, a compilation of U. S. Government Statements on China, from 1948 to the late 1960s, as well as extensive files documenting the events surrounding the Tiananmen Square uprising and reaction to them.

did.unittitle: Exchanges - General

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 2, Exchanges - General, in RG 9, contains collected reports and reference files on exchanges and visits to - and in some cases from - China by individuals and other (non-NCUCSCR) sponsoring organizations, from the early 1970s to the early 1980s, especially. Materials include lists of travelers to China and files of trip reports, sorted by subject. Also significant are policy memos and formal exchange proposals the National Committee negotiated with the Chinese government for the period from the early 1970s up to 1983. Series 2 also includes various briefing materials; an alphabetical card file of individual and institutional contacts in the U.S. with connections to China, for the 1970s; and a clippings card file on Chinese delegations to other countries, 1971-1977.

did.unittitle: Separated Oversized Material
Exchanges to China

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 3, Exchanges to China, contains records of the trips the National Committee organized for its Members from 1981-1984, along with trip reports and reference files on individual visits or delegations to China arranged under the auspices of other organizations. Series 3 also includes a few reference Lists of Trips and Exchanges (from the mid-1960s to the late-1970s), arranged by date and by subject category, and including a listing of NCUSCR-facilitated visits.

Please note that there is some overlap between Travelers and Other Organizations files in Series 3 and the Trip Reports and Other Visits files that are found in Series 2; material on visits to China can be found in both series.

did.unittitle: Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 5, Conferences, Seminars, Workshops, and Dialogues, notably contains files on the National Conference on the United States and China, which was held in Washington, DC, April 28-30, 1965, and which provided some impetus for the creation and organization of the NCUSCR the following year. Records of the National Committee's March 1971 seminar on Taiwan and American Policy make up the other significant component of the Conferences series in RG 9. Other materials include a descriptive list of Conversations from Wingspread recordings, 1972-1979, as well as a few files that complement records in other parts of the NCUSCR collections.

Programs, Projects, and Proposals

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Programs, Projects, and Proposals series in RG 9 contains records relating to the National Committee's Field Staff programs, 1968-1976; the Luce Foundation – funded Civil Society Project, 1995-2000; and the Scholar Orientation Program (SOP), from the mid-1980s through the late 1990s.

The Field Staff files cover the program for the period 1971-1976 and include program and grant correspondence and reports, as well as correspondence with individual university field staff offices. Files on Berkeley and Stanford date from 1968 and concern efforts to establish an office in the Bay area. Early records concerning the other university field staffs (1967-1973) are found in RG 2 (FA1184).

A three-year grant from the Henry Luce Foundation in 1997 funded a project to explore the development of civil society in China, particularly with regard to the localization of decision-making authority and privatization of the economy. Through education and exchange programs, joint U.S. – China working groups shared knowledge and experiences in working to address problems of environmental protection in Northeast China and the privatization of vocational education in Guizhou province.

Series 8 also includes Scholar Orientation Program files for SOP trips # 60 – 70, COP # 74, and TEP # 77 (spanning the period 1993-1998), plus various files for the 1980s- 1990s concerning program administration, visit planning, readings, etc. The files in RG 9 complete the fuller run of SOP records found in RG 3 (FA1185).
Finally, the series includes a card file of potential Speakers and Contacts, providing names, qualifications, and other information on a wide range of China experts.

did.unittitle: NCUSCR Presidents' Files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 14, Presidents Files, in RG 9 contains the chronological correspondence files (plus some general correspondence and speech files) of Arthur H. Rosen, who was president of the National Committee from March 1975 through 1987. David M. Lampton succeeded Rosen as president in 1988 and served until December 1997. His correspondence files are not found in the NCUSCR collection, but RG 9 does include copies of several of his talks, articles, and papers, as well as memos to the National Committee and congressional testimony, for the period 1987-2002.

did.unittitle: Clippings and Reference

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Clippings and Reference series in RG 9 significantly documents two subject areas in particular, namely, U.S. Government Statements on China, 1948-1968; and the development and unfurling of events surrounding Beijing Spring, the Tiananmen Square uprising, the government crackdown, and its aftermath, 1989 and later.

The U. S. Government Statements on China file consists of a typed compilation of statements and excerpts by U. S. leaders and officials, and several associated files of notes and clippings. The compilation appears to be a working manuscript, but it is not clear if it was ever published or otherwise distributed. Other files in this series concerning Public Opinion on China, 1966-1976, and official visitors and other Travelers to China, 1970s, provide a kind of complement to the government statements materials.

Files on the Beijing Spring and Tiananmen contain clippings and contemporary press reports, eyewitness accounts, editorials, and other materials that document the events and consequences of the uprising and its repression and reactions to them.

Finally, Series 15 also contains several files on relations between China and the U.S.S.R., as well as other general files on topics such as the Chinese economy, civil society, relations with Taiwan, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series 18, Special Formats - General, consists of various working files and other poorly identified materials, housed on floppy disks. The series is at present unprocessed; folder titles reflect content information such as we have it.
Other digital materials in RG 9 are described within the appropriate subject series.
See also FA1318, for available NCUSCR audiovisual material.
